#DidYouKnow King Kamehameha’s original name was Pai’ea, which means “hard-shelled crab.”

After emerging from hiding in Waipiʻo valley at age 5, he was renamed Kamehameha, or The Lonely One. #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3pcp0hXoAAafGk.jpg

#DidYouKnow King Kamehameha the Great was known as a fierce warrior, yet also demonstrated compassion for others? 

Kānāwai Māmalahoe, also known as his law of the splintered paddle, protected the most vulnerable, guaranteeing safety to all. #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3oX7UUXoAI-n3q.jpg

RT @oha_hawaii THE ORIGIN OF KAMEHAMEHA DAY

The first Kamehameha Day was celebrated on June 11, 1872, by proclamation of King Kamehameha V, Lot Kapuāiwa. The King wanted to honor his grandfather and founder of the Hawaiian Kingdom, King Kamehameha I. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3n5xyrVgAEKe2l.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3n5xyuVkAQGZx1.jpg

#DidYouKnow King Kamehameha was a trained warrior—known for his legendary strength and physical abilities?

In his honor, our Field Representative made his own King Kamehameha Day run to the Kamehameha Schools Office on Kauaʻi. Imua!

#KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3oQxv8XEAEUPb9.jpg

The fourth and final statue of Kamehameha stands in our Nation’s Capitol at Emancipation Hall. It was dedicated on April 15, 1969 and is one of the heaviest statues in the collection—weighing in at over 6 tons!

My DC staff shared this photo from Washington! #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3oGdM_WEAQ-W_9.jpg

#DidYouKnow there are 4 commissioned statues of King Kamehameha in total. The first/original statue was lost traveling from Europe after a shipwreck near Cape Horn in South America.

It was later found and placed in North Kohala in 1912 at the Kohala Court House. #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3oD0vBWQAImE9D.jpg

#DidYouKnow King Kamehameha oversaw the construction of his great 1,000+ canoe Peleleu Fleet from Hilo Bay?

Many of the war canoes were capable of carrying over 100 warriors and were hewn from koa trees harvested from the forests of Mauna Kea. #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3n3Pu7WYAgy8_N.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3n3PvaWQAs0hY8.jpg

Happy King Kamehameha Day and Aloha Friday!

Known as a fierce warrior, wise diplomat and profound leader, King Kamehameha I was the first to establish a unified Kingdom of Hawaiʻi.

Today, we respect his legacy. #KamehamehaDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nTjPSXwAMUiv6.jpg

I was incredibly proud to introduce the legislation that led to the naming of the Dorothy Braden Bruce Post Office Building.

For 70 years, Dorothy kept her story a secret. Now, our community will always remember her pivotal Allied codebreaking efforts.
https://www.wtvr.com/news/local-news/dorothy-bruce-post-office

I was honored to hear from Dorothy Bruce's family and friends at today's ceremony, as well as author @lizamundy who features Dorothy’s story in her book Code Girls: The Untold Story of the American Women Code Breakers of World War II. https://twitter.com/RepSpanberger/status/1403416581292630016 QT @RepSpanberger During WWII, Dorothy Bruce served in a top-secret group of code-breaking women, protecting the lives of American troops.

Today, her family officially unveiled the plaque renaming the Sycamore Square Post Office in Midlothian as the Dorothy Braden Bruce Post Office Building. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0taXIAEjdeY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0tiXwAcvvw1.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0trWEAMoxwy.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0t4WUAMiE0u.jpg

I was proud to introduce the legislation that honored her life of service.
https://www.wric.com/news/local-news/chesterfield-county/president-trump-signs-spanbergers-legislation-to-open-post-office-after-world-war-ii-code-breaker-in-midlothian/

Sworn to secrecy, Dorothy’s unit worked to disclose the locations of Japanese ships in the Pacific and intercept enemy supply movements.

Dorothy Bruce was one of thousands of American women serving as codebreakers at the time, and she passed away in 2019 at the age of 99.

During WWII, Dorothy Bruce served in a top-secret group of code-breaking women, protecting the lives of American troops.

Today, her family officially unveiled the plaque renaming the Sycamore Square Post Office in Midlothian as the Dorothy Braden Bruce Post Office Building. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0taXIAEjdeY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0tiXwAcvvw1.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0trWEAMoxwy.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3nv0t4WUAMiE0u.jpg

RT @fairvote Today let’s talk about the #FairRepAct, which was just reintroduced in Congress by @RepDonBeyer

Whether you’re completely new to this reform, or a long time fan, there are lots of benefits to discuss so let’s get started.

https://www.fairvote.org/fair_rep_in_congress#why_we_need_the_fair_representation_act http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E3m1vK3XoAMgY5G.jpg

RT @CynthiaRTerrell I am thrilled that @RepDonBeyer has re-introduced the #FairRepresentationAct because we need a #21stCentury democracy where split vote & plurality winners are a thing of the past, gerrymandering is eliminated, & we all have the power to elect candidates who represent us! https://twitter.com/RepDonBeyer/status/1403442397212778500 QT @RepDonBeyer Our democracy is under siege.

America just saw the worst attack on our constitutional order in 150 years. A widespread attack on voting rights is unfolding, and gerrymandering will soon make it worse.

In the face of these threats, I am reintroducing the Fair Representation Act.

RT @_cingraham Multi-member districts would fix a *lot* of our current problems and almost certainly make folks across the political spectrum happier with their representation. Here’s an explainer on them from earlier this year https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/03/01/break-up-two-party-system/?outputType=amp https://twitter.com/repdonbeyer/status/1403443040237371397 QT @RepDonBeyer The Fair Representation Act is a bold reform to change the way our elections work and ensure every voter's voice is heard. The bill would (1) establish multi-member districts (2) drawn by independent redistricting commissions with (3) Members elected through ranked choice voting.

You can read more about the Fair Representation Act in the Atlantic, the Washington Post, and from the Editorial Board of the New York Times.

Our democracy is in danger. This is an idea whose time has come.

Whether it's whitewater rafting down the New River, hiking the scenic trails in Grandview, sightseeing through the historical town of Thurmond, or exploring the unique botanical ecosystems that exist within Sandstone Falls, the @NewRiverNPS showcases West Virginia's very best!

With over 80 million acres of land, America’s #NationalPark system offers visitors young and old limitless opportunities to explore. The more than 400 @NatlParkService-managed sites are truly one of our nation’s greatest treasures!

In 2020, 1.4 million visitors spent ~$65.3 million in local gateway regions while visiting @NatlParkService lands in West Virginia - which supported over 900 jobs, $25.8 million in labor income, $43.1 million in value added, & $76.5 million in economic output to the #WV economy.

GREAT NEWS: @NatlParkService announced that visitor spending in communities near national parks in 2020 resulted in a $28.6 billion benefit to the nation’s economy and supported 234,000 jobs in hospitality, recreation, and transportation.

.@RepJayapal, myself, and @LanceGooden are introducing the Ending Platform Monopolies Act. This bill prohibits Big Tech monopolies from selling products in marketplaces they control. .@RepJoeNeguse and @RepSpartz are introducing the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act to give DOJ and FTC the resources they need to police monopoly power, at no cost to taxpayers. Read their bill here. #AStrongerOnlineEconomy https://cicilline.house.gov/sites/cicilline.house.gov/files/documents/Merger%20Filing%20Fee%20Modernization%20Act%20of%202021%20-%20Bill%20Text%20%281%29.pdf

.@RepJeffries and @RepKenBuck are introducing the Platform Competition and Opportunity Act . This bill makes it harder for Big Tech monopolies to buy and kill of their competitors. Read their bill here. #AStrongerOnlineEconomy https://cicilline.house.gov/sites/cicilline.house.gov/files/documents/Platform%20Competition%20and%20Opportunity%20Act%20-%20Bill%20Text%20%281%29.pdf

.@RepMGS and @RepBurgessOwens’s Augmenting Compatibility and Competition by Enabling Service Switching (ACCESS) Act makes it easier to quit a social media platform and take your data to a competitor. Read that bill here. #AStrongerOnlineEconomy https://cicilline.house.gov/sites/cicilline.house.gov/files/documents/ACCESS%20Act%20-%20Bill%20Text%20%281%29.pdf

I’ve authored the American Innovation and Choice Online Act with @Lancegooden. This bill prohibits companies like Amazon from manipulating their marketplaces to promote their own products. You can read the bill here. #AStrongerOnlineEconomy https://cicilline.house.gov/sites/cicilline.house.gov/files/documents/American%20Innovation%20and%20Choice%20Online%20Act%20-%20Bill%20Text.pdf
We have introduced five bills today to strengthen our laws to hold tech monopolies accountable, and build #AStrongerOnlineEconomy.

.@DaniLang_DC: "In addition to early voting, we know that equitable vote-by-mail practices increase voter participation. These practices include universal eligibility, reasonable application and submission procedures, and opportunities to correct technical errors."

.@DaniLang_DC (@campaignlegal): "Early in-person voting access, which ensures that the fundamental right to vote does not hinge on one schedule on a single day, is an essential component of our voting system."

.@gilda_daniels: “Voters of color encounter a plethora of problems in their attempt to exercise their right to vote. When polling places close or other barriers are erected to access the right to vote, the burden and cost of voting increases tremendously in communities of color.”

.@gilda_daniels: "The Act has been severely weakened and endures constant assault. The Shelby County v. Holder...sounded the alarm for legislatures to once again pass laws that would make access to the right to vote harder and impede the ability of voters of color.”

.@gilda_daniels (@adv_project): "Blacks have been in this country for over 400 years and have only been voting for 56. This is a testament to the power of the Voting Rights Act - it removed barriers such as literacy tests, poll taxes, and other disenfranchising mechanisms..."

Herron: "States have discretion over the how much early voting they want to offer...the ones that do can choose the number of days and hours. The research that's primarily come out of the state of Ohio shows that more early voting leads to more voting in general."

Herron: "One question that people in election administration address is: Is the cost of voting roughly the same for all Americans? This is a question about equal treatment, it's different from the question: Is the cost of voting low?"

Michael Herron (@dartmouth): "A key concept in the field of election administration is what's called the cost of voting. This refers to a cost, not necessarily financial cost, that individuals must pay in order to participate in democracy. One cost is time, called a time tax."

.@mimimarziani (@TXCivilRights): “Since the Supreme Court's Shelby County decision, there have been a slew of voting law changes in Texas that have made it more difficult for Black and Latinx Texans to vote. Texas then, sadly is a prime example of why Congress must act now..."

.@kevintmorris: "As my research documents, mandatory minimum resource requires set by individual states are routinely ignored. Take just one example among many - in 2018, 31 of South Carolina's 46 counties...had more voters per machine than allowed under state law."

.@kevintmorris (@BrennanCenter): “We need to focus on equitable experiences on Election Day - that is, ending the racial wait gap, not only on equal distribution of resources. In other words, as much attention needs to be paid to the quality of resources as to their quantity."
Jesselyn McCurdy (@civilrightsorg): "Voters of color will bear the brunt of these new restrictions in the most significant assault on voting rights since the Jim Crow Era."

.@pettigrew_stats: “Researchers have found that voters who experience a long line are less confident in the integrity of the electoral system as a whole - they're less likely to believe that their ballot will be kept secret or that their votes will be properly counted."
